review_title: Teaching undergraduate chemistry labs and tutorials was great for general chemistry courses
job_title: Chemistry Teaching Assistant in Hamilton, ON
pros:
- general 1st and 2nd year courses are great, short labs in a 3 hr time slot provides relaxing atmosphere for students
- marking assignments was usually awarded with pizza =))
- pay is great
- invigilation of exams is nice
- new teaching assistant are generally assigned to the entry level undergraduate chem course, and later may choose to teach an upper level course. Good flexibility in choosing which courses to teach.
cons:
- because there are so many different teaching assistants, the teaching is not uniform. Some TAs decide not to teach some skills to students due to the desire to finish the lab early and leave. This is not monitored and uniformity should be enforced.
- upper level courses for students enrolled in the chemistry program required a significant amount of extra uncompensated time. This extra work was not rewarded or recognized. General chemistry courses require much less amount of time with the same pay grade.

pros: This entirely depends on your supervisor. Some are great (such as mine) while others are terrible. With the right guidance and access to great equipment, McMaster can be great at allowing you to advance your research. If you plan on continuing in academia, this can be a challenging but overall good experience.
cons: There is very little focus on making sure you are well suited to a career outside academia which is a huge problem given how competitive the field is. The atmosphere of being a graduate student is extremely discouraging at times and frankly, graduate students are not a priority for the university, whether they advertise otherwise. Being surrounded by people who don't know what they will do next and post doctoral fellows in their 8th year of waiting for a permanent position as a professor  makes for a grim atmosphere.

review_title: Excellent benefits pkg., workload moderate, quality of learning depends on supervisor and willingness to work overtime
pros: As a TA in humanities,  I've found the remuneration fair, especially considering CUPE benefits. The workload is moderate, although usually more than we are technically paid for.
cons: Whether a TAship helps foster a mastery of teaching, marking, lecturing, or leading discussion depends on the quality of the course, the supervisors' guidance, and the TA's willingness to work overtime on workshops, mentoring students, and attending lectures. TAs often refuse to do those things because of hours of work limitations, which sometimes leads to sub-par work and minimal skill-building. There are few opportunities for TAships for 5th-year students, and almost none for recently-graduated PhDs.

review_title: Great place to work - friendly staff, learned a lot
job_title: Transcription Assistant for Students With Disabilities in Hamilton, ON
pros: This was a student job, but I learned a lot of skills that I was able to apply in future employment areas. I felt that working with students with disabilities gave me an edge in becoming proficient in working with people in the community with mental illnesses.
cons: Needed to be a self-starter. Not much supervision in the job in which I was employed, which was great on most days, but if you are someone who requires motivation from an outside source, this may not be the best job for you.

pros:
- The university can boast about it Infrastructure and Resources for scientific research
- It attracts one of the highest Funding for university research in Canada
- Creation of various institutes provide diverse expertise
- Positive work atmosphere
- opportunity to meet talk and listen to eminent scientists
cons: The only not so positive point can be peer pressure..... though this can be subjective and open to ones on interpretation. In my view, a great research environment at McMaster University while encourages one to perform high standard research, the situation also creates pressure for researchers to come out with big publications.

review_title: Very nice communities and social activities but low salary
pros: There are many opportunities for leadership development by getting involved with student societies. Free workshops for different soft skills are also available. Graduate students are free to take undergraduate courses as well, as long as your supervisor and the course instructor says yes.
cons: Medical insurance is limited compared to what domestic students have. Tuition fee for international students is very expensive so even with scholarships and bursary, the monthly income is minimum.

pros: I've worked at McMaster a few times. Most recently on a short contract. My supervisors and coworkers were great. Everyone is keen on seeing each other succeed. I enjoy the commitment mindset that everyone has. It's a pleasured to work at McMaster.
cons: There is misunderstanding of what it means to provide support for the projects undertaken at the institution. I found some people were negative about the move taken towards a new central system. I think the system will work well, in time. Every new software has growing pains. I found some supervisors weren't engaging their employees enough.

pros:
Great understanding of your needs, especially if you are a student (i.e. time off for study/exams, flexible schedule)

Lots of great perks like free lunches, employee appreciation week, opportunities away from the workplace, etc. 

Very laid-back working environment--not stressful at all.
cons:
Some employees don't carry their own--they are almost too laid back and put a lot of things on others or rush to finish things last minute. 

Hard to move up to other positions or keep jobs that are only contract/part-time as people are very stagnant in roles.

review_title: It is an awesome school... the mount of knowledge both academically and professionally is great
pros:
Networking, the university offers a lot of networking events with industry leaders that when used correctly can get you ahead in the market place
Research Tools; McMaster offers a username and a password that gives access to a lot of valuable search engines
cons: The compensation for graduate students needs to be revised because it is the full-time job while studying and the healthcare plan covers non of the medication that I need!

pros:
Unforgettable experience, to this day I still think about this job and have a niggle sometimes.
My co-workers are now my friends for life. It was a really great experience. There were many activities that you can choose to do or not. The experience depends on how you want to shape it.
cons: Very late hours, expect to work from 9pm to 3pm regularly, and sometimes be on-call until 12pm the next day.

pros: sociable, enjoyable associates, good pay, good benefits, good community, good environment, pleasurable to work with students, can be positively demanding and challanging during the busy time of the day, decent benefits
cons: located in hamilton, far from my home, very hard to reach with local transportation as the buses are being rerouted to not go through campus and alot of students usually fill up the buses and they become full and dont stop for additional passangers on their way to school.

pros:
McMaster is really good at communicating information with staff. The overall atmosphere is positive. There are career development opportunities to experience different positions.
The Director I have is very supportive and has a lot of external knowledge. I have learned a lot from her.
McMaster promotes and supports continuing education. They support it financially but the amount is capped. This is an adequate amount unless you will be taking expensive courses/programs.
The benefit program is standard, nothing really exceptional.
cons:
I find it difficult working on a day-to-day basis because of the lack of other employees skills. Some of the finance managers have no education in finance or external experience. I once asked if revenue should be deferred at year end and the manager didn't know what that was. 
The position I hold is an exciting position but I can't do my job well because the lack of technological infrastructure does not allow me to do my job properly. The university is working on a new system but it will take over 5 years. Until then my job is painstakingly manual.
The union's influence has created a lack of competition with external positions for those who hold a more senior position. The entry level jobs are well paid (more than average) and intermediate positions are appropriate, but senior level positions are underpaid (less than average, $20k less for me). These are unionized positions but the same is true for non-union.

pros:
~Great community - both colleagues and students were wonderful, supportive environment, very positive
~Lovely setting - campus is gorgeous, close proximity to Toronto, Hamilton is a truly an under-appreciated city
~Fair pay & Benefits - self-explanatory
cons:
~A lot of bureaucracy - Felt as though I spent a lot of my time on paperwork, a great number of committees that failed to accomplish anything, overall things happened a maddeningly slow pace
~Not much vision for change - administration is content with the way things are, hard to start new initiatives, vision statements are generally vague

pros:
If you are a student, it's great since the hours are very flexible.
The people you work with are great. Very easy to swap shifts in case of emergencies.
Through this job, you get to learn more about the course that you are teaching than before. 
A lot of extra material and aid is provided to help the students better.
cons: There is serious lack of management presence initially, so getting things started is a bit bumpy. Sometimes, last minute requests to cover tests and marking which were not initially noted in the orientation.

pros: Flexible schedule, lots of vacation time, great supervisor, benefits galore!!!  So many things that are positive
cons: Trying to find parking.  Walking through the student centre around lunch.  Too many students, not enough staff

pros:
- Among small teams there are GREAT people, and great work being done!
- Great benefits and fair salary
- Opportunities to move around/try different things IF you are in the union
cons:
- Overall management is usually not qualified, they rise to their level of ineffectiveness
- Layers and layers of bureaucracy
- No real motivation to change things (depends on department)
- Much of the unionized staff have no motivation to change/improve ("that's not my job" attitude)

review_title: Colleagues are great, but we need better MBA students
pros: Get to work with basically good people despite a challenging environment
cons: Compared to undergraduate business students on the McMaster main campus, most MBA students are total snobs. There is such a massive sense of entitlement and such a bloated set of expectations. They all think they're better than you and they all expect to just step on over you into some CEO's chair. Most of of them don't know how to dress or write a cover letter and at least half of those don't think you have anything to teach them about it. These are the students the school administration tells us to go out and get co-op placements in the business community for. It's hard not to giggle a little bit to watch these kids get smeared by the world. Sometimes you help them get theirs. One perk of this job is that you can help people get what they deserve whether or not daddy and mommy can pay their tuition to send them here.

pros: Some people you work with are genuinely great, and not fake/pompous like a lot of your other co-workers. Likewise, some students are legitimately good members of the community, but a lot of them are also spoiled brats that take anything and everything you do for granted and treat you a little better than a servant.
cons: There are too many to list.

pros: Generally the people that you interact with on daily basis are very nice. The working environment is simulating and the city has lots of potential.
cons: Commuting from Toronto is easy, if you were to take public transportation. If you are thinking about driving everyday, that might be an issue. Some areas in downtown and more to east may not be nice to live at.

review_title: Good pay but stay on top of how much you have worked; can easily start overworking yourself.
pros: Pay was good, came out to about $42 CAD / hour. Haven't had a problem with any Professor I TA'ed for.
cons:
Being a TA was a component of the graduate student compensation package. I'm unsure how available this position is for people applying externally.

Sometimes you end up going over the amount of hours you are supposed to because it can be a lot of work (marking). Make sure you are on top of your hours.

job_title: Campus Tour Guide in Hamilton, ON
pros:
- Great position if you are passionate about McMaster and what it has to offer
- Opportunities for further leadership, as a tour guide leader
- flexible hours
cons:
- Lots of changes with respect to our supervisor - I have been working for 2 years, and experienced 4 different supervisors
- The recruitment office has around 30 guides on staff, which can make getting hours during less busy months difficult

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Hamilton, ON
pros: As a graduate student teaching assistant I was provided sufficient in-person training as well as additional resources for professional development. Experience will vary depending on courses and supervisors.
cons: Occasionally the work expected exceeds what can be reasonably completed in the the number of hours that you are paid for. Take a good look at your hours of work form before signing it (if you are a new TA, ask someone who is experienced to look at it for you) and be sure to keep track of your hours.

job_title: Business Development Manager in Hamilton, ON
pros: team atmosphere, great exposure to all types of people from all walks of life, great education in terms of access to cutting edge research, friendly culture, people seem to care for the students (which is rare in a large university), excellent salary,
cons: too much politics between professors and departments, too much bureaucracy exists in some funding applications, but overall there are very few cons at this place.  really a dream place to work, if you ask me.

pros: Working for McMaster as a student offers low pay, but excellent experience that makes you feel confident about your future work prospects.
cons: Low pay for student employees is the biggest con by far; scarcely more than minimum wage, the amounts of funding flowing through the institution should certainly offer a little more compensation to the students.

pros: McMaster has a large research community that is well supported by numerous successful faculty. The people are social and make for a great experience.
cons: there are very little cons, however, having moved from the west coast I would say the biggest con is the winter and all the snow and cold that comes with it

job_title: Assistant Web Developer in Hamilton, ON
pros: Amazing people to work with. Culture is very opened and diverse among employees. My team consisted of 3 people and were filled with projects.
cons: Turn around time is slow. Enough work to keep busy but, at times can require more people. There are times when the office is completely quiet and not much work is done.

job_title: Computing and Programming Teaching Assistant in Hamilton, ON
pros: get to interact with first-year students, and you get to solve the problems with their codes. always fun to sit down, figure out the mistake, and discuss with the student
cons: very hard to find suitable time that fits in your schedule and if you have no time available you can't work...also marking process is a little bit tedious with Avenue

pros: Great collegues and excellent research being carried out at McMaster.  I learned everything I wanted to and more in my time spent at Mac.  The faculty are working on excellent and challenging problems.  A great institution to launch into the field of modern scientific research.
cons: The salary as a researcher is a poor, and the work is extremely challenging.  Only consider this line of work if you are truely passionate about learning and discovery.

review_title: Great atmosphere but administration can improve.
pros: A great work environment, especially in hospitality service. Working around students is great because they are usually much friendlier than the general public.
cons: The administration in terms of scheduling shifts can be quite horrible. Management cares more about cutting costs than a providing a quality work environment for the workers.

pros: McMaster University have world leading research facilities, and one of the best place to conduct scientific research. University Library provide access to many scientific journals in all different subjects. McMaster University also provide very competitive salary package for its faculty and staff members.
cons: Research activity mostly focused on fundamental research.  Professors interested in publish papers rather than commercializing their research results.

review_title: Low pay, good way to refresh fundamental knowledge
pros:
UHIP and compensate GSA plan together with dental plan guarantee basic life insurance.
To be a RA/TA is a good way to refresh previous fundamental knowledge.
Work with awesome Profs. is amazing experience.
cons: The monthly pay (TA/RA in lieu) can only support your personal living cost in Hamilton. If you have dependent family members, you'd better apply for additional Graduate scholarship (not easy) or search for a part-time job (ask for admission of your supervisor).

review_title: Great place to study and work
pros: Departmental organization was top notch, with plenty of opportunities to advance.
cons: Organization of the school left something to be desired.  For example, inadequate loan distribution system for a school of its size meant many students took weeks to receive necessary funds.

review_title: Mcmaster Hospitality Service - Centro dining unit
job_title: Food Service Worker in Hamilton, ON
pros:
- Supervisors, Head Chefs were splendid
- Casual workers are basically student 
- Free food (if worked >5,5hrs), free pop all day everyday
- Hearty and intimate workplace, respect is set a priority
cons:
- workload goes up if a foo doesn't show up for their shift
- no set training procedures for new employees

job_title: IntroPsych Teaching Assistant in Hamilton, ON
pros: I get to work part-time as a teaching assistant while being a full-time student. I love interacting with the first years on the topic of psychology!
cons: The supervisors should keep a closer eye on the TAs to ensure that all of us are fulfilling the same role and responsibilities. Not to say that anyone isn't completing their role, but I am just suggesting that they have some sort of system in place to ensure quality teaching.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant No Degree in Hamilton, ON
pros: flexible hours, time of to focus on studies, reasonable pay
cons: no room for undergrad pay increase, if you were a student you were hired at the base salary and there was never any talk of increasing your wage based on performance or returning employee

pros: Salary is slightly above the regional average for the type of role that I was in - this seems to be the norm for managerial salaries. Unfortunately, salaries seem to be well below the regional average for unionized, administrative positions.
cons: Poor organizational culture supported by a tense labor relations environment. Weak management. Very weak financial controls. Poor IT support for finance - very poor implementation, training and reporting processes for a newly implemented finance system. HR department lagging in terms of industry-wide best practices in talent management, leadership development and labour relations approaches. No pension plan for new management staff, but unionized staff still can join the pension plan.

pros: The working environment is really good. People are very friendly here. Get a lot of instruction during work
cons: The city is not very modern. It usually takes a lot of time to go to work since the public transportation is not that satisfying

review_title: Mostly pros and a few cons, but overall great.
pros: Positive environment, great people, interesting work, difference-making work on the large scale, world renowned.
cons: Pay could be higher, employee protocol could be more clear or implemented more consistently. It's a great place to work but you may find yourself looking elsewhere due to low pay.

pros:
This was among the most rewarding jobs I've had. 
It's really great to be able to work with students, and see growth.
cons:
It can be difficult to balance work and study at the University.
In some cases there could be more course-specific resources for new Teaching Assistants.

review_title: Good experience but salary is low.
pros: The communication with profs and students are efficient and creating. In addition, I found I learnt a lot of new knowledge which I didn't know or didn't pay attention.
cons: The salary is very low for graudate TA and work load is not well balanced. In my department we need to TA in two terms in each year. The TA work takes a lot of time and does influence my research.

review_title: Good pay and good for resume
pros: The pay is great,and the work schedule is very flexible and not too time consuming
cons: Your experiennce may vary depending on the prof youre working for. Lets just say my prof was not the most organized person in the world and didnt respond to emails often so there were times I'd be in  the tutorial and have no idea whats supposed to be happening

pros: I worked as a teaching assistant while doing my masters. The pay was excellent and aside from teaching tutorials the hours were very flexible.
cons: Sometimes I would work over the 10 hour per week limit, especially when marking tests or large assignments. This balanced out with other weeks where I worked less.

review_title: Great place as a student to grow
pros: I started off as a 4th year student doing a summer full-time research assistant position and they kept me on through the year as part-time. It was a great opportunity to learn and attain skills. It was great for making contacts. I got great references from my professor and supervisors.
cons: Very competitive atmosphere, either you have a lot of work or nothing to do sometimes.

pros: It's a good choice to study engineering in MAC. The faculty members are awesome and smart and can give you help in the filed of researching. You can learn a lot here.
cons: The pay as a TA/RA is not as high as expected.

review_title: Don't work at Mac if you are under 55 years of age
job_title: Someone Who Works There in Hamilton, ON
pros: easy job where you lay back and do basically nothing but surf youtube all day.  Great if you're close to retirement
cons: management is a joke - won't make decisions on anything. Slowest moving company on any decisions I have ever seen

review_title: Speaking about one of the social science branches.
pros:
Good people to work with in the department.
Very high grad student wages ($40/hr vs $25/hr for the same position in schools in the west coast).
cons:
Not very well funded compare to similar ranked schools. Politics makes funding inefficiency apparent.
Department colleagues don't seem to be very close.
Young profs work young profs and old work with the old. You get the picture.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Hamilton, ON
pros:
Very inclusive environment to be in
Strives for improvement of the school
Makes you as an employee a better person through training and employment
Great hours if you want to work a lot
cons: This is a very university environment and you deal with the same thing year after year. The students always don't have a clue as you progress in your job they always stay at the same stage

job_title: Part-time Postdoctoral Researcher in Hamilton, ON
pros: Love the university, the culture, and the guidance for academic positions. The department that I am in (Psychology, Neuroscience & Behaviour) is very friendly, very collaborative, and there are lots of social gatherings
cons: If you're looking toward academia, it's great, but if you're looking to branch out, say into industry, there's not enough preparation. Although, I feel like this is probably a theme at most universities.

review_title: I performed my PhD studies in Physics at McMaster and was very happy with my experience.
pros: Great grad student environment, I had a phenomenal supervisor and got to perform interesting research and travel to a lot of conferences
cons: Work life balance as a PhD student can be tricky to find, long hours in the lab and a lousy pay (especially as an international grad student), lots of TA:ing

review_title: Excellent people, and upper management is getting better
pros: Stable hours, beautiful campus, chance to take classes, usually inclusive for most roles, mostly wonderful people.
cons: Upper management is still working on improving themselves, and it is an ongoing process. There is not as much upward mobility as in other workplaces.

pros: Very good people, hard working and helpful. Hours are flexible and managers are down to earth people
cons: Not much really. Unless you get stuck in the dish room working 8h on weekends everything else will be a walk in the park

review_title: A good place to start working right after your school
pros: Friendly environment, less pressure, support for personal development, full-benefits, union protection, good balance between work and family, tuition assistance for your children
cons: decentralized research groups, theoretically driven, intensive research environment

pros:
1. Beautiful environment, it feels very refreshing, relaxed and comfortable when you walk along the lakeshore besides the school after daily work. 
2. Nice and kind faculties,  feel like a family, they always smile.
3. Benefits,Benefits.
4. I met a good supervisor
cons:
1. Job is nonchallenging, no top-level to do.
2. Not the most exciting industry.
3. Some supervisors may push you more than others.

review_title: It is a good place to start your academic career.
pros:
The working environment is very friendly. Profs and technicians are always willing to help you.
You have a large space to develop your ideas and skills.
cons: The number of positions for post graduate students is very limited. Most of the time it depends on whether your supervisor has enough funding to support you as a research assistant.

pros: This university offers some nice academic environment, beautiful campus, good gym facilities. There are so many different active student groups to engage a large variety of choices. The libraries are fantastic.
cons: Research facilities are OK but not necessarily top-shelf. In electrical engineering, there is not enough corporation with industry. The income for graduate students with TA position is low.

review_title: Form diagnosis, treat patients,  write prescriptions (when doctor not necessary)
pros: Great atmosphere,  friendly colleagues,  new equipment,  adequate supplies, I really enjoy having the ability to help the medical and mental health of the citizens in my community.
cons: The government has taken away a lot of the resources necessary to most proficiently help the patients in  timely manner. Jobs are becoming increasingly precarious.

review_title: McMaster University is a great place to work for if it wasn't for work environment dictated by bullies!!
pros: Great pay and benefits, career growth opportunities, job security.
cons: Unfortunately some departments are dictated by bullies (upper management) even the university can not break the culture. a lot of emotional abuse, toxic work environment and lots of gossip.

job_title: Summer Research Student in Hamilton, ON
pros:
Learn at your own pace and gain knowledge from working with other graduate students at the lab.
Participated in reviewing courses under the instructor.
cons:
No overtime for any bonus pay
Research had a lot of extra hours that were not paid.

review_title: The extent of satisfaction depends on your supervisor
pros: Exposure to people of various research areas. Possibility to learn knowledge from related areas.
cons:
Inadequate communication with supervisor. If your supervisor is super busy, you may have to work all by yourself, or follow the instruction of posdocs or engineers, who might not know well about what you should do. 
Bossy senior managers

pros: McMaster is a very good institution to be a part of with many excellent professors and exciting ongoing research.
cons: No real cons. As a graduate student, the health insurance is not great (nor is the pay, but that is not specific to McMaster).

review_title: Wonderful place to work and learn
pros: Consistently renewed contracts. Great staff.
cons: Duties and hours increased due to the influx of foreign students in need of additional assistance. University support services for Teaching Assistants diminished over time leaving new TAs without support or workshops to gain teaching skills.

pros:
Great interactions with in residence students offering academic and social support.
The residence staff and managers are very good at giving feedback and receptive to change.
cons: Hours vary significantly depending on specific circumstance and different factors. But if you love the job, long hours are also fun.

review_title: A good place to learn and make friends.
pros:
To make quite a lot of friends.
Learn form the professors.
It is also a good place to study and work at the same time as a graduate student.
cons: Help the students with their courses. Have find some good result on my own research which will help lots of people in the future, I think.

pros: It is an awsome university with friendly staff.  Great opportunity to learn about different research projects (not just your own) and you can get a feel of where is the limit of every technology.  Not a fast pace environment (depends on supervisor).
cons:
No benefits because I was not full time.
The offices can be boring without windows.

pros: Good benefits, some flexibility in hours (depending on your manager), interesting work
cons: Union is strong here (which can sometimes help, sometimes seems to create additional layers of hoops to jump through), people worked in silos in my department, lack of stability with funding

review_title: A Stable Environment With Quality Benefits
pros:
Benefits package is high quality
Stable environment for full-time employees (although contractors can be strung along)
Fully-featured employee assistance program (career building, financial and mental health counselling, etc.)
cons:
Depending on department, the environment can be fairly static and change-averse
Opportunities for professional development and advancement are limited

pros:
Pretty location
Good Pay
Excellent Benefits plan
Excellent time off
cons:
People promoted by virtue of time served - very little progressive thinking by management
Silo's between faculties 
Too much political interference from faculty members - hold way too much power
Claim that they are innovative but penalize those who fail when trying to innovate

pros: very good atmosphere, I worked in mathematics and statistics department, you can even ask him to schedule the course which you want to teach.
cons: There's nothing cons about the university, everything is excellent. The department is not big.

review_title: A good place for students working there part time
job_title: Food Service Assistant in Hamilton, ON
pros: Most of poeple working there are students like u, they would accommodate your exam schedules as long as you tell them ahead, managements have been working with students for a long time
cons: It's just a part time job for students which means basically no room to grow, minimum salaries

pros: Great faculty to work within Science and Health Sciences. So many diverse work opportunities for undergrad and graduate students of all levels.
cons: Work opportunities are hard to find (unless you watch Mosaic like a hawk). Regardless of faculty, HR processes are extremely slow and require a lot of followup to get something simple done.

pros: It has very good prof with high knowledge and good management. I like the staff as well. they are usually kind and they do their best to help you.
cons:
Very good environment for research job
It has very nice profs. with high knowledge. Their management on the research project is good as well.

review_title: Department: Student Success Centre- Good job for someone just starting out in their career.
pros: There is  good work life balance.
cons: Difficult to advance up the ranks, you have to have good contacts. Also, there is surprisingly high level of office politics.

review_title: Great University to pursue graduate studies
pros: Many friendly people who can keep you sane when work gets tough. Hamilton is gorgeous and has tons of great restaurants and bars
cons: You won't get industry-level funding for projects so you may have to make experiments work with minimal equipment, or old equipment. Get used to reading old manuals

pros: Excellent institution, lot of talented person, dedicated staff... one of the best research center in Canada in Biomedical Engineering.
cons: Working with student can be a little bit frustrating since they are in training and need time to time to spend hours supervising their work. But it is the same time in every University.

review_title: Ok place to work at, not good if you want to work for a progressive institution
pros:
Close to Home
Good Slaray/benefits
Relaxed environment, Good work/life balance
cons:
Not progressive environment
Too relaxed environment
Takes too long to get things done
Cost ineffective institution

pros: They provided flexibility to set my T A hours, the administrative team was very nice and organized and very hard workers.
cons: There were not good channels of communication and not a good support when I started to have health problems, they were only concerned about performance so I decided to leave.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Hamilton, ON
pros: Enjoy the atmosphere of working at McMaster. Beautiful campus and city to live in as well! I work in the department of Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE), and have thoroughly enjoyed my time as a teaching assistant.
cons: Some archaic professors who still work in the department and hold back research/course potential.

job_title: Teaching and Research Assistant in Hamilton, ON
pros: Good department, well compensated, TA pay was good with reasonable hour expectations, Graduate students had input in department decisions.
cons: Post-doctoral research not easily available, little reprimand for poor supervisors, drop in compensation after first year, Little support for beginning careers after academia

pros: You are on your own to do your research. You only interact with your direct supervisor which fortunately in my case is a very reasonable person.
cons:
Pay is low. Only temporary for a few months after graduation.
You don't get to know many people in your field. Hard to make connections.

review_title: good place to work very stable, and friendly staff.
pros: good place to work very stable, and friendly staff. very fresh with new students every year. great location to live.great pay / benefits.
cons: some times very slow, lots of paperwork, very hard to move up, some times dead end job. terrible e-mail system.

review_title: Innovative, well organized program for graduate students
pros:
- Administration is flexible, understanding
- Professor-TA interaction is facilitated well
- Seemingly solid relationship between McMaster University and CUPE local 3906
cons: Limited job availability for certain faculties, e.g. health sciences, leading to lack of full-time TA employment, or necessity of taking on courses in different faculties.

pros: Surrounded by supportive coworkers. If you encounter any problem, there are protocols to make sure you have their back. Nice and safe environment.
cons: Heavy workload, balancing between work and life can be a challenge to people with many part time jobs. Besides, not much of a con.

pros: Great benefits. Beautiful campus.
cons: Feel badly for the custodial staff who are underpaid and were treated poorly in the last negotiations. Hard to watch waste happening - various ways, i.e. new software system being implement and it's going very roughly

pros: McMaster is a nice secure place to work, the people are kind and the benefits are great. Including health/ dental and education benefits.
cons: Just as any university or company in the public sector, things can be slow moving at times but generally a great work place.

review_title: A fun place to learn and grow!
job_title: Research Assistant/Teaching Assistant in Hamilton, ON
pros: Fun team and environment to learn and grow. A good place to do mistakes which give you a great experience.
cons: No clear structure as most of the grad studies. Mainly depends on self-discipline and self-commitment which is challenging. Lack of some resources. Low pay.

pros: I work in the engineering department, doing semiconductor related research. The hardware are good. Have access to many advanced equipment  such as cleanroom, MBE, ion implantation, to use for research.
cons: The staff in the university are general slow paced.  They take months of vacations each year..

pros:
Close to Campus
Fun work environment
Lost of chance to be promoted
There is a decent pay
Great opportunity to improve communication and leadership skills
cons:
Upper management can sometimes have unrealistic expectations
Upper management tends to be a little out of touch from the clients

pros: The working environment is very peace. Superior always giving help to employees. And there is very rear work pressure in my department.
cons: The McMaster University Campus is kinda large, sometime walk from one building to the other would take you more than 10 minutes.

job_title: Student Tour Guide in Hamilton, ON
pros: Perfect for students because working for the school allows you the freedom to have them work around your class schedule.
cons: At the moment, I can not think of any cons that McMaster University has posed to me while working for them.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Hamilton, ON
pros: I was provided with all of the necessary tools and support to complete my job responsibilities. I also liked the other TA's that I worked with.
cons: The level of support and tools depend on the supervisor and department you TA for.

pros:
They understand you are a student, thus extremely accommodating
Hours can be very flexible, managers are nice, location cannot get any better if you are a Mac student
cons: Gets insanely busy with no extra benefits (you don't even get the basic benefits offered at corporate locations)

pros: Reasonable wages, lovely people, beautiful campus, Hamilton is actually a great city
cons: Students referred to as "income generating units", the approach to post-secondary education is consumeristic rather than based on scholarship, novel thinking, pushing boundaries, and learning useful skills

review_title: Very open and friendly atmosphere, plenty of creative assignments
pros: Great facilities, great people. Feels like a family all striving towards a similar goal. Very open minded and open to new ideas
cons: Difficult to advance within the university without actually holding a professor position.

pros: Good working environment, opportunities for multidisciplinary research.
cons: Salaries of graduate students are very low to live with a small family

job_title: Human Resources Advisor in Hamilton, ON
pros: For TMG employees - competitive salaries,  performance reviews help salaries move quickly, competitive benefits, management professional development allowance, and management compensation days off in lieu of overtime.
cons: Work life balance is hard to maintain, understaffed,  more support needed.

pros: Well paid Teaching assistant positions. It's a good practice if you want to become a teacher in the future. Recommend if you are currently studying there.
cons: Nothing much too say. As a student part-time job, there's not much to expect.

pros: As a teaching assistant, they provide you excellent pay and good references from professors to advance yourself to other jobs.
cons: The teaching assistants do not have many hours so you cannot depend on the pay as a significant source of income.

review_title: Good place for Engineering and Science
pros: Small city, low living cost, density campus, nice environment, nice people in the department. Famous with Chemical, Material, biochemical and Medical areas. Guarantee teaching assistant position for adding some salary.
cons: Some professor can be very mean.

pros: McMaster is leader in research in Canada
cons: Grad Student support is not good. Payments are low. Even getting an external scholarship does not help you. University will take most of it.

pros: know much more ppl in the fresh year, and get more volunteer experiences
cons: had to do time management with full load semesters, especially during the exam week period, its hard to manage exam conflicts with school activities

pros: Enclosed and beautiful campus, excellent programs are offered, great self-learning teaching methods, small class size, modern libraries, student centre is a fantastic idea with good options of food
cons: Not that much to do in Hamilton (compared to Toronto)

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Hamilton, ON
pros:
-Exciting research
-great treatment from staff
